results.title: [London, 1963 - 1964]
results.brief_description:
This silent, black-and-white footage of some of the major landmarks of London was shot in 1963–1964 by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett.

Opens with the Royal Marines Band playing, filmed as they march past the Duke of York Column and Waterloo Steps.

00:00:46:00 then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Alec Douglas-Home, farewelling a visitor on the steps of Number 10 Downing Street (the headquarters of British government).

00:01:11:00 camera pans down Nelson’s Column (a monument in Trafalgar Square, central London, commemorating Admiral Horatio Nelson.) We then see scenes of Trafalgar Square, with the National Gallery building and fountain both visible.

00:01:22:00 camera lingers on the equestrian statue of King Charles I, with the church of St Martin-in-the-Fields in the background.

00:01:28:00 London traffic, with the camera focussing especially on cabs (taxis).

00:01:43:00 the Admiralty Arch.

00:01:49:00 double-decker London bus in front of some classic 1960’s style adverstising signs in Piccadilly Circus, with the Eros statue visible.

00:02:04:00 Eros statue in close-up.

00:02:22:00 Underground (railway) sign in close-up, followed by scenes in the Underground itself; ticket queues, escalators, and a train coming into a platform.

00:02:46:00 “Piccadilly Circus” station sign visible on the wall of the train tunnel

The film ends with footage of the tunnel, shot from the moving train.

group_siblings.title: [Construction of the Water Tower at Fletcher Jones Factory, Warrnambool, 1967]

production_dates.notes: Creation date recorded on donated film can.

results.title: [Robert Lennox Suggett Collection]
results.brief_description: This collection consists of two short, silent 16mm films made by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett in the 1960s. One shows the construction of the water tower in Warrnambool, Victoria, in 1967, while the other features footage shot in London between 1963 and 1964.
results.description: This collection consists of two short, silent 16mm films made by Australian photographer Robert Lennox Suggett in the 1960s. One shows the construction of the water tower in Warrnambool, Victoria, in 1967, while the other features footage shot in London between 1963 and 1964.

results.title: Dead centre
results.brief_description: There are many kinds of centres: centres of dart boards, baby health centres, fathers who are the centres of their family. There is also the centre of the road: the drivers who stay on it are likely to end up in the dead centre - the Coroner’s Court.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

The first half of this film is long scenes of the sea interchanged with a koala in a tree.

Later we see Edith Penington holding the koala which appears to be domesticated.

Much of the rest of the film is following this koala as it eats and climbs trees.

There is also a brief moment with a penguin and some sheep.

The film finishes with Edith Penington fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 koala in a tree
00:02:17:00 Dr Penington climbing a tree to pat the koala
00:04:13:00 Edith Penington cuddling a koala bear as it is fed
00:04:35:00 the koala bear climbs into the trees
00:04:55:00 Dr Penington cuddling the koala bear and feeding it
00:06:20:00 penguin being released running to its burrow
00:06:23:00 Dr Penington climbs into a tree with the koala
00:06:38:00 Edith Penington fishing

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows Dr Raymond Penington’s girls in the late 1930s and brief scenes of other members of the family.

While the film is focused around his three daughters the main theme throughout is the youngest daughter, Jocelyn Penington.

The film is located mainly in two places, the back yard at home and the beach, though there is a brief scene in the snow. It covers a short period as the girls grow up.

While a very personal film, of interest for a general viewer includes fashion of the time which includes all generations.

There is a scene which appears to be a birthday party where games of the time are being played such as statues.

Also seen is an old tricycle and scooter.

The film finishes as it started, with the family at the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Edith Penington and daughter Jocelyn at the beach
00:01:21:00 Jocelyn Penington shuffling on her bottom in the yard at home while her sisters, Margaret on a tricycle and Vivienne on a scooter, play around her
00:05:08:00 the women and girls play with a kitten in the yard
00:05:43:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington running around in swimwear through a sprinkler
00:06:12:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington playing ring a ring a rosy
00:06:39:00 Dr Raymond Penington playing ring a ring a rosy with his daughters
00:08:04:00 the Penington family in the snow
00:09:06:00 girls playing games in the back yard (possibly a birthday party)
00:10:42:00 a puppy and rabbit interacting with each other
00:11:47:00 Penington girls and their grandparents
00:14:50:00 Penington family at the beach

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Simon McCutcheon.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This Penington family trip, captured on film, focuses mainly on dams visited in Victoria, Canberra and New South Wales including dams of the Kiewa Hydroelectric scheme, the Hume Dam in Albury and the old Cotter Dam in Canberra.

Also shown is the Tronoh dredge in Harrietville, which was active from 1942 to 1954 and was one of the largest bucket drenches to operate in Victoria collecting 53,814 ounces of gold.

There is a scene of the Clover Dam under construction and views of the town of Mount Beauty before the addition of the Mount Beauty pondage (circa 1946-1950).

Of historical interest is the Gundagai Timber Rail Bridge and steam train. The bridge spanned 819.4 metres, opening 12th Oct 1903 and closed March 1985.

Also seen is the original Snows Shopping Arcade in Sydney.

Monuments seen are the Captain Charles Sturt expedition monument in Gundagai, Corowa’s First and Second World War monument clock, and the J.B Patterson Monument in Castlemaine, Victoria.

Penington family members seen include Edith and her daughters Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 views of the Kiewa river and kids playing
00:00:37:00 old bulldozer moving logs – view of a lady with a vintage pram
00:01:27:00 Tronoh Dredge, Harrietville (1942–1954)
00:02:40:00 scenic view of Mount Beauty and beginnings of the township at the foot
00:02:50:00 Clover Dam under construction circa 1945–1950
00:03:42:00 the Bogong Dam
00:04:33:00 view of Mount Beauty
00:07:18:00 Margaret and Vivienne Penington collecting milk from the milkman
00:08:05:00 the Hume Dam and Murray River, Albury
00:08:54:00 Bethanga Bridge
00:10:24:00 Gundagai Timber Rail Bridge and steam train
00:10:48:00 monument for Captain Charles Sturt, built in 1829
00:11:13:00 men hauling machinery off a truck that has crashed off a bridge
00:12:26:00 Snows Shopping Arcade, Sydney
00:12:42:00 old Cotter Dam, Canberra – before the extension was added in 1951
00:13:30:00 Corowa First and Second World War monument clock
00:13:35:00 street in Corowa showing many cars of the era
00:14:18:00 J.B. Patterson Monument
